description: Flytipping and bin problem Trundleys Road SE8: Constant problem on this road, bins causing obstruction, rubbish and flytipping in area of HMOs. This has been reported from as far back as 2016 and is still not sorted. Letters have been sent to these properties asking them to comply with the law and council regulations but still the problem persists and is even getting worse. Time for the sanction to be imposed and fines issued. So many people are fed up with this!

description: Noise from basketball court back of 44-54 Albacore Crescent: The basket ball court is accessible 24 hours a day, with the sound of the ball, human noise, and music often as early as 5.00 and late into the night, sometimes as late as 2.00. It is a significant issue, disturbing sleep every night and causing huge distress to me and my family, particularly my grand daughter and 88 year old mother with Alzheimer's Disease. The court is too close to the residential houses given that it is constantly open. The problem has been going on for at least 10 years. I have registered a complaint to Lewisham Council but have received no response.
title: Noise from basketball court back of 44-54 Albacore Crescent

Tiny bin always overflowing with rubbish: The bin is an inadequate size (about half size of a normal public bin) and rubbish is very often overflowing from it and strewn across the surrounding area. This is an area many people visit with children to play on the boulders and in the river and picnic at and as such needs appropriate bin facilities. The rubbish spilling out of the current bin ruins an otherwise pleasant spot by the Pool River. Please provide a new bin that has greater capacity and is not vulnerable to foxes scavenging through the rubbish.

Dangerous fence at Nesbit Close
detail: There is a very dangerous wobbly fence on top of a large hill. The fence moves and is very close to homes below the hill. Non residents use the space in the fence as a short cut which damages the fence more making the gap bigger and wobbly. I originally reported this incident on 7th February 2022 to James however nothing has been done unfortunately and the fence continues to get weaker. The fence is now leaning back and is only a matter of time before it falls completely. Please can you advise. Many thanks

detail:
Not sure why you, Lewisham council seem so reluctant to do anything about this location after years of reports and plenty of photographic evidence. I will not use your own report system, I will continue to use FIX MY STREET as it leaves it publicly for all to see.

Multiple vehicles, no number plate, all being stripped down for parts on the PAVEMENT. Where people are meant to walk. Engine oil, gearbox oils and other car fluids have totally stained the pavements here.

Loads of rubbish dumped in and around the vehicles. It's quite obvious a local resident which I know you have already had dealings with, is just allowed to go using the public highway for his commercial dealings.

All crap in the road for people to get punctures, items dumped on the grass, neighbor allowing the guy to use his front garden to store old tyres, pallets and all other rubbish.

Last time there was 5 children sitting in all this oil sifting through wiring looms. . sorting out car parts like this is some sort of 3rd dump.

But you, Lewisham council say there is a lack of evidence. Open your eyes.
title: Lack of evidence you say?

Scrapyard: Please read properly.

I never directly reported the untaxed vehicles, the category was FLY TIPPING yet you ask me about the vehicles number plates then say no further action. Rude.

The number plates are removed and hidden which is an offence. If you sent someone there you would know that for yourself instead of expecting the public to spoon feed you the information.

There's also a set of metal gates that goes to Phoenix community councils new building site opposite all the guys vans, this has rubbish dumped there also.

You totally ignored the fact that there's oil all over the pavement, car parts scattered everywhere and other automotive fluids due to this persons actions. Would you like to live next door to scrapman so all his rubbish can be outside your house?

description:
Graffiti: My recent report on graffiti on buildings and shutters was responded to by Lewisham Council in that if I notified them of a particular building they would try to include that in their programe for cleaning due to not enough funding or staff to take on any large scale cleaning to clear it. It surely needs someone from LBC to look at the state of the High Street and come up with something more positive to clear the problem.

What's happened to the CCTV cameras in the High Street. I'm sure the shop keepers can offer some help, it can't do their business much good trading in such a messy Street. The police must know the tags and the names/addresses of the people causing the damage Shops should not be allowed to sell spray paint or marker pens to under 21's.
title: Graffiti
detail:

detail:
Hello, An unknown substance has been poured/spilled out of a window belonging to a Lewisham Homes property (flat 5 Stephens Court, 82 Endwell Road). This mess is now down the wall below and over the windows of the two flats below.

Lewisham Homes do not manage the whole of Stephens Court. However, they do rent flat 5 from the owner to provide social housing. Please can you check this as my other report was rejected.

Please can you arrange for someone from Lewisham Homes to attend and clean this up. Thank you.

detail: Last year a brick pillar on the western corner of St Margaret's Square fell down - perhaps it was hit by a vehicle. Someone has moved it from the middle of the pavement and into the hedge, which is nice, but the smashed up brickwork remains on its side. It's unsightly and needs rebuilding in line with the rules for the conservation area.

Bridge over the River Quaggy: The bridge over the River Quaggy is on the boundary of Bromley and Greenwich with Bromley being the highway authority for the bridge and to the east of the bridge. West of the bridge Lewisham is the highway authority, and north of the bridge Greenwich is the highway authority.

Shown in the picture is the shiny new 10T weight restriction sign installed at Bromley taxpayers' expense to the east of the bridge. There are no weight restriction signs to the north of the bridge (Greenwich) or to the west of the bridge (Lewisham).

Lewisham assert that the bridge now has a 40T weight limit (presumably believing it has been strengthened) and they gleaned this information from Bromley.

Either Bromley has squandered taxpayers' money on the new sign or Lewisham has made a mistake in removing the 10T limit signs.

To further confuse matters, there is a second bridge over the River Quaggy this time on Mottingham Lane, again on the boundary of Bromley and Greenwich, but with Greenwich the highway authority. Could it be that this bridge has the 10T limit.

Whatever the answer, this matter needs investigating as a matter of urgency, and the investigation should include liaising with Lewisham and Greenwich highway authorities to get to the bottom of this matter and ensuring that all three highway authorities display the correct signage for the bridge.
detail:
The bridge over the River Quaggy is on the boundary of Bromley and Greenwich with Bromley being the highway authority for the bridge and to the east of the bridge. West of the bridge Lewisham is the highway authority, and north of the bridge Greenwich is the highway authority.

Shown in the picture is the shiny new 10T weight restriction sign installed at Bromley taxpayers' expense to the east of the bridge. There are no weight restriction signs to the north of the bridge (Greenwich) or to the west of the bridge (Lewisham).

Lewisham assert that the bridge now has a 40T weight limit (presumably believing it has been strengthened) and they gleaned this information from Bromley.

Either Bromley has squandered taxpayers' money on the new sign or Lewisham has made a mistake in removing the 10T limit signs.

To further confuse matters, there is a second bridge over the River Quaggy this time on Mottingham Lane, again on the boundary of Bromley and Greenwich, but with Greenwich the highway authority. Could it be that this bridge has the 10T limit.

Whatever the answer, this matter needs investigating as a matter of urgency, and the investigation should include liaising with Lewisham and Greenwich highway authorities to get to the bottom of this matter and ensuring that all three highway authorities display the correct signage for the bridge.
title: Bridge over the River Quaggy

description:
Bins full again - lack capacity because Lewisham Council inaction: For over a year I have documented and reported that our block lacked recycling bin capacity. I have reported this to Pinnacle, Regenter and Lewisham Council and none have taken any action to resolve this, they just put the finger at the other.

Two of our recycling bins are full again. One (the cardboard bin) has been full for a week, the other (bottle) for a few days. The third bin with bottle slots may only be partially used so residents have no choice but to put cardboard and other items in the normal waste bins.

Because of Lewisham Council and Pinnacle's ongoing neglect approx 25-30% of our recyclables have been placed in the wrong bins for over a year. Neither care about this and apparently no-one is accountable.

It is beyond incompetence and just a waste of tax payers money - Lewisham Council;
title: Bins full again - lack capacity because Lewisham Council inaction
detail:
For over a year I have documented and reported that our block lacked recycling bin capacity. I have reported this to Pinnacle, Regenter and Lewisham Council and none have taken any action to resolve this, they just put the finger at the other.

Two of our recycling bins are full again. One (the cardboard bin) has been full for a week, the other (bottle) for a few days. The third bin with bottle slots may only be partially used so residents have no choice but to put cardboard and other items in the normal waste bins.

Because of Lewisham Council and Pinnacle's ongoing neglect approx 25-30% of our recyclables have been placed in the wrong bins for over a year. Neither care about this and apparently no-one is accountable.

It is beyond incompetence and just a waste of tax payers money - Lewisham Council;

For over a year the recycle bins in our block, especially the only cardboard bin have been overflowing and residents are forced to throw recyclables in the normal waste bins.

Like previous complaints one bin has been full again for over a week and overflowing for a few days because Lewisham Council continues to fail to deliver this service. Lewisham Council points its finger at Pinnacle and Pinnacle points back and in the interim residents are stuck in the middle of these two corrupt and incompetent organisations having paid for a service which neither provider says it is accountable for.

Lewisham Council points its finger at Pinnacle and Pinnacle points back and in the interim residents are stuck in the middle of these two corrupt and incompetent organisations having paid for a service which neither provider says it is accountable for.

Colony of pigeons in building toxic droppings everywhere: Pigeons have moved into the empty corner shop roof. There is in excess of 30 birds and its increasing. There is large amounts of droppings on the floor surrounding the shop. Pigeon droppings are toxic. They are becoming a nuisance for the surrounding properties too as the population increases.
detail: Pigeons have moved into the empty corner shop roof. There is in excess of 30 birds and its increasing. There is large amounts of droppings on the floor surrounding the shop. Pigeon droppings are toxic. They are becoming a nuisance for the surrounding properties too as the population increases.
title: Colony of pigeons in building toxic droppings everywhere

detail: Our recycling bins were again not collected by Lewisham Council. One bin is full and the two others are at 80-90% because regardless of the missed collection we lack bin capacity. Lewisham Council has been aware of this for over a year but failed to take any action. Neither Lewisham Council or Regenter (Pinnacle) will take responsibility for these ongoing failings which mean 1/4-1/3 of our recylcling has to be placed in normal waste bins. Both Lewisham Council and Pinnacle have stated that the other is responsible and their is no mechanism to hold either to account under the failed Regenter RB3 PFI contract
title: Missed recycling collection again and overflowing bins
description: Missed recycling collection again and overflowing bins: Our recycling bins were again not collected by Lewisham Council. One bin is full and the two others are at 80-90% because regardless of the missed collection we lack bin capacity. Lewisham Council has been aware of this for over a year but failed to take any action. Neither Lewisham Council or Regenter (Pinnacle) will take responsibility for these ongoing failings which mean 1/4-1/3 of our recylcling has to be placed in normal waste bins. Both Lewisham Council and Pinnacle have stated that the other is responsible and their is no mechanism to hold either to account under the failed Regenter RB3 PFI contract

Recycling bins not collected again: For over a year Lewisham Council has failed to consistently collect the recycling bins for this Regenter (Pinnacle) managed block. Documented complaints have been made to both but still no action has been taken. Our bins were full before Easter and were not emptied this week so again residents have to use the normal waste bins to dispose of recyclables. Lewisham Council's contractors do not have the capacity to manage and deliver this contract to the required collection frequency and the estate does not have enough bins to cope with increased bin pressures due to COVID behavioural changes. The bins have not been contaminated but regardless of the evidence this seems to be the Council's go to excuse for not have enough refuse collecting capacity.
title: Recycling bins not collected again
detail: For over a year Lewisham Council has failed to consistently collect the recycling bins for this Regenter (Pinnacle) managed block. The bins have not been contaminated but regardless of the evidence this seems to be the Council's go to excuse for not have enough refuse collecting capacity.

description: Broken glass on path into Durham HIll (park): Posting here but nothing will get done about it, council will just mark it 'internal review' which seems to mean ignore it and hope it goes away there has been broken glass on the path into Durham Hill (park) from Mooreside Road for the last week. most has been brushed aside by people kicking it out the way as bigger bits are against the green. like most glass breakages on the roads, the council do sod all about it and leave it up to the public to clean up (Q, where do we send the invoice for this or do we deduct it from the poll tax you just put up?)

description: Dog mess (now cleaned up): We frequently have most unpleasant dog mess by our car. We would like an official council sign as a deterrent.
title: Dog mess (now cleaned up)
detail: We frequently have most unpleasant dog mess by our car. We would like an official council sign as a deterrent.

Since April 2020 our blocks ongoing lack of recycling capacity has been exacerbated by COVID. Residents have informed then complained about this to Pinnacle and Lewisham Council. Every week or so our recycling bins are overflowing and residents are forced to place a significant amount of recyclables in the normal waste bins. This has been documented for at least 10 months and the problems still continue but Lewisham Council has wrongly stated that the block has adequate capacity. Our recycling bins have been full for over a week so we continue to waste recyclables. Photo attached.
title: Lack of recycle bin capacity
description: Lack of recycle bin capacity: Since April 2020 our blocks ongoing lack of recycling capacity has been exacerbated by COVID. Every week or so our recycling bins are overflowing and residents are forced to place a significant amount of recyclables in the normal waste bins. This has been documented for at least 10 months and the problems still continue but Lewisham Council has wrongly stated that the block has adequate capacity. Our recycling bins have been full for over a week so we continue to waste recyclables. Photo attached.

Access blocked: The concierge at the distillery tower locked the access gate 6 months ago and refuses to open it. My understanding is that this is a public right of way and has to remain opens during daytime hours. I have difficulty in accessing the rear of my building and have to take my bike the opposite way through the building instead of out in to the courtyard and beyond.

description: Dangerous car parking on corner near Co-op: Cars are parking vertically on the corner of Stanstead Road and Rockbourn Road & obstruct the left view of motorists emerging from Rockbourn Road causing them to get into the centre of the road. Personally had three near accidents at that point because of this. Cars are parked outside the new Co-op so cars heading towards the 205 from Stanstead Road are already overtaking parked cars at that point and meet any vehicle emerging from Rockbourn Road. This issue has been reported to the local Councillor and has been an issue for many months.

detail:
There is a very large and overgrown tree outside 77 Lewisham Way, which overhangs the pavement and neighbouring property. This tree has never been pruned or inspected and poses a significant potential danger to passers by.

Large branches have been coming off the tree and falling onto the ground and whenever there are winds the tree sways violently.

In addition, the fence next to the tree is damaged and seems to have collapsed - leaving several rusty nails exposed and a large piece of rusted metal grating with branches sticking out of it.
title: Large overgrown tree and rusted nails outside 77 Lewisham Way
description:
Large overgrown tree and rusted nails outside 77 Lewisham Way: There is a very large and overgrown tree outside 77 Lewisham Way, which overhangs the pavement and neighbouring property. This tree has never been pruned or inspected and poses a significant potential danger to passers by.

Large branches have been coming off the tree and falling onto the ground and whenever there are winds the tree sways violently.

In addition, the fence next to the tree is damaged and seems to have collapsed - leaving several rusty nails exposed and a large piece of rusted metal grating with branches sticking out of it.
A big bush: On way in to Melrose close there is an over grown bush which is causing a problem with cars just missing each other perhaps it can be cat back before is accident happens .

description: Non cutting of grass and privets: The 'green chain walk' in Woodbank Road has not had the grass cut for nearly 3 months. even during lockdown a person with a strimmer or ride on mower could have kept this down. other areas too. green on the corner of Capstone Road and Lame Rock Road also the one in the road with no name between Moorside Road and Capstone Road - opposite the Good Shepard church [PW / Education Facility on your map} both side of the road are very over grown and there has been a tin 'unit' put on there for months. looks like a council thing. also overgrown privets making it impossible to walk on the pavement when cars are also, badly, parked. corner of Moorside Road and Whitefoot Terrace. Corner of Capstone Road and Durham Hill come to mind
title: Non cutting of grass and privets

detail: Logged 3 years ago and labelled as fixed, but IT IS NOT FIXED. A car crashed into the wall and demolished the brick wall (behind the bins in the photo) and the fence (as visible in the photo). The car nearly killed me walking on the pavement too, and the speed people drive down Brookmill Road is therefore a far larger issue. Don't wait until someone dies to do something. Speed bumps are a must.
title: Demolished wall and fence (car crash)
description: Demolished wall and fence (car crash): Logged 3 years ago and labelled as fixed, but IT IS NOT FIXED. The car nearly killed me walking on the pavement too, and the speed people drive down Brookmill Road is therefore a far larger issue. Don't wait until someone dies to do something. Speed bumps are a must.

Developer’s hoarding covered in graffiti: Green Developer’s hoarding on Morden Lane is covered in graffiti, which has now spread to nearby private properties, and wall which is part of a conservation area. Developer is negligent in their maintenance of this; they erected it so should also maintain it in an acceptable condition. Currently it’s damaging the area’s environment and bringing anti-social behaviour/ crime here as a result.

Fence already pulled down by gate onto public pavement but now is also pulled entirely away at the other end by the railway. Rubbish being thrown on to Site of Importance for Nature Conservation via this massive hole.
detail: The sections of pulled down fence are huge now and various issues as a result - people can get on to the land and damage/vandalise the scout hut & SINC site all listed with Lewisham as assets of community value. Rubbish being dumped on the site and pathway obstructed with fencing.

detail:
Despite numerous responses today that the problem is fixed, it isn't.

Whilst most stones are not on the Calmont Road carriageway, they are on the Hillbrow Road carriageway. As the photos show, road markings indicating a bump in the road are partially covered and the direct route used by pedestrians crossing Hillbrow is covered by stones. These are particularly difficult to walk on for those in 'equality' categories eg the elderly, infirm and carers with prams. Further more, because the stones are in very close proximity to Calmont Road (and generally are all over it), this is dangerous for cyclists and in addition, car wheels can flick the stones into the air dangerously.
title: Problem not fixed: Stones in Calmont Road
description:
Problem not fixed: Stones in Calmont Road: Despite numerous responses today that the problem is fixed, it isn't.

Whilst most stones are not on the Calmont Road carriageway, they are on the Hillbrow Road carriageway. As the photos show, road markings indicating a bump in the road are partially covered and the direct route used by pedestrians crossing Hillbrow is covered by stones. These are particularly difficult to walk on for those in 'equality' categories eg the elderly, infirm and carers with prams. Further more, because the stones are in very close proximity to Calmont Road (and generally are all over it), this is dangerous for cyclists and in addition, car wheels can flick the stones into the air dangerously.

Station Road - overgrown vegetation: The north side of Station Road (by the taxi rank) has overgrown vegetation that has already covered the seating and in encroaching onto the pavement. The area is littered with discarded rubbish (the bins are often overflowing) and has been rat-infested in the past. I'm aware that the area has been baited, in the past.
title: Station Road - overgrown vegetation

title: Shingles on Calmont Road from Hillbrow
detail: The shingles from the un-adopted road Hillbrow Road are deposited onto Calmont Road and are never cleared cleared. This makes this section of Calmont Road uneven and unstable. The other day I was unable to push a pram along this section and had to move to the centre of the road to avoid it which is dangerous to myself and my son.

detail: This pothole has been here for AGES. I reported a long time ago and it’s still not been fixed. It’s actually gotten bigger since I first reporter it and appears to be sinking. It sits next to what appears to be a water mains supply stopcock on the walkway in front of Lewisham Park Towers. It’s close to the front of the Kemsley block building.

Lamps out on the footbridge: The lamps along the footbridge next to the park have been out for two years and are a danger as drug addicts and dangerous criminals prey on vulnerable residents. Why has lewisham council ignored all requests for the last two years to have the lamps replaced? A boycott of council taxes is an option if these lamps are not replaced so residents can feel safe when crossing during the dark

London and Quadrant have added external pipework to their flats with no planning permission and also probably breaching building regulations and in addition this pipework poses a potential danger to members of the public as it fronts onto a public footpath.

Planning enforcement should please investigate
